title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act mandates the development of protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with states, public health officers, and attorneys general in this process. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act requires protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Secretary must consult with states, public health officers, and attorneys general. "Hazardous agents" refer to dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines "hazardous agents" as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. Dangerous biological agents are those listed in the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 and not exempt from regulations. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines "hazardous agents" as dangerous biological agents and chemicals listed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996. The term "dangerous chemical" refers to chemicals listed by the Secretary within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines "hazardous agents" as dangerous biological agents and chemicals listed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996. The term "dangerous chemical" means a chemical listed under subparagraph (B) and a list of such chemicals must be developed within 45 days of the Act's enactment by the Secretary in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board. The Hazard Investigation Board, as per the Clean Air Act, will identify chemicals known or anticipated to cause serious health effects, including those listed under the Act. These chemicals may be considered for use by individuals intending harm. The Hazard Investigation Board will identify chemicals that may cause serious health effects or death, including those listed under the Clean Air Act. Protocols specific to each hazardous agent will be developed under this provision. The Hazard Investigation Board will develop agent-specific protocols for hazardous chemicals to address public health emergencies resulting from intentional releases. The Secretary must establish priorities and timeframes within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will establish priorities for hazardous agents within 45 days of the Act's enactment and develop protocols for the highest priority agent promptly. The Secretary will establish priorities for hazardous agents and develop protocols promptly, aiming to complete each protocol within 45 days. The provisions of a protocol include ensuring uniform application in each public health emergency involving the hazardous agent. The provisions of a protocol include ensuring uniform application in each public health emergency involving the hazardous agent, coordinating with emergency response personnel, and providing medically appropriate information to individuals present at sites. The Secretary will establish priorities for hazardous agents and develop protocols promptly, aiming to complete each protocol within 45 days. The provisions include coordinating with emergency response personnel, providing medically appropriate information to individuals present at sites, testing and treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and responding to emergencies. The Secretary will periodically review and revise protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving hazardous agents, including testing, treating, and decontaminating affected individuals and sites. Other provisions may be included as determined appropriate. The Secretary periodically reviews and revises protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving hazardous agents, whether accidental or intentional. Other provisions may be included as deemed appropriate. The Secretary may grant a development exemption for protocols for hazardous agents if existing protocols meet requirements. A report listing exempt hazardous agents must be submitted to Congress within 30 days of enactment. Exemptions do not affect the need for review and revision of protocols. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006.
